answers: sisters [or sissie; accept Our Sister Killjoy or My Sister, the Serial Killer; prompt on siblings; prompt on serial killers by asking “what other role titles the novel?”]
Braithwaite [or Brathwaite; accept Oyinkan Braithwaite or Kamau Brathwaite or E. R. Braithwaite]
rings [accept The Lord of the Rings]
parts: Name this title role of the murderous Ayoola in relation to Korede, the narrator of a bestselling 2018 novel set in Lagos.

The author of My Sister, the Serial Killer, Oyinkan, shares this surname with several other authors of the African diaspora, including the Barbadian poet Kamau and the Guyanese author of To Sir With Love.

Korede stages a robbery as an excuse to destroy one of these objects that the handsome doctor Tade bought for Ayoola. The Two Towers is the second volume of a high fantasy trilogy titled for these objects.

answers: Epirus [accept Despotate of Epirus; accept Pyrrhus of Epirus]
parts: It’s not the Morea, but religious silver coins were produced by the mint at Arta that operated under the “Despotate” of this ancient region of western Greece and Albania. Home to the oracle at Dodona, this region’s Molossians were led by a king who defeated Rome at Heraclea and Asculum.

The 1258 destruction of Baghdad diverted Silk Road trade to this body of water, which greatly enriched the Empire of Trebizond. Genoese ships sailed through the Dardanelles and Bosporus to reach their Crimean colonies on this sea.

The Sultanate of Rum traded luxury goods for food with the Empire of Nicaea under John III Vatatzes, who married into this noble family of his father-in-law Theodore. It also included the Renaissance author of Erotomata, Constantine.

answers: novel of manners [or comedy of manners]
parts: Name this novel. Later in this novel, that character rebuffs a man for his confession by asking “why with so evident a desire of offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me against your will?”
Pride and Prejudice is this type of novel that focuses on the social conventions and customs of a particular society or section of a society.
This author of Pride and Prejudice wrote five other complete novels, all of which revolve around the social customs of the British gentry.

answers: Italy (The architect is Antonio Sant’Elia, and the building is the Palazzo della Civiltà Italiana.)
Antoni Gaudí (The apartment building is the Casa Milà.)
Le Corbusier [or Charles-Édouard Jeanneret; accept Le Corb]
parts: An architect from this country imagined massive ziggurat-like buildings with floors connected by external walkways and elevators in his vision of the “New City.” A stark-white rectangular building in this country’s capital has a flat façade dominated by a dense 6-by-9 grid of arches.

This architect’s unrealized 1908 plan for his enormous Hotel Attraction in New York was reconsidered after 9/11. He also designed an apartment building with wrought-iron balconies nicknamed “the stone quarry.”
This architect included cross-shaped skyscrapers connected by a grid of greenery in the design for his ideal city, the Ville Radieuse. This Swiss-French modernist also designed the Villa Savoye.
Name this man, honored at the Onam harvest festival. He defeated the devas after Vishnu initially refused to join the conflict against him.
Mahabali was defeated by an avatar of Vishnu who took this form. Shiva’s dancing form Nataraja dances on the head of one of these creatures named Apasmara.
Brahma washed the big toe of that avatar of Vishnu, Vamana, and collected the water that formed this sacred river.

answers: differential equation [or diff eq; accept specific types such as linear or partial differential equations]
Runge–Kutta (“ROON-guh KOOT-uh”) methods [or RK or RK4 methods]
Störmer–Verlet (“ver-LAY”) method [or Verlet integration; or Störmer’s method]
parts: Name these types of equations that relate a function to its derivatives.

Euler’s method is a simple member of this family of numerical methods named for two German mathematicians. In the most common, fourth-order method of this name, the function’s slope at the beginning, end, and at two different estimated midpoints are weighted and averaged.

This method is often used for solving systems governed by Newton’s equations of motion. Like the leapfrog method, it is symplectic and time-reversible, and it calculates the position as twice the previous position minus the position two steps prior plus a delta t squared.

answers: Nim Chimpsky [or Neam Chimpsky; prompt on Chimpsky]
XOR [or (bitwise) exclusive or; do not accept or prompt on “or”]
parts: Name this monkey who, in an experiment led by Herbert Terrace, was raised by humans and taught sign language.
In game theory, a nimsum is equivalent to the bitwise form of this basic logical operation.
Corporal Nym is a character that appears in this playwright’s plays Henry V and The Merry Wives of Windsor.
Name this compound that is mostly used as a solid source to generate gaseous butadiene in situ.

Gaseous butadiene can be reacted with one of these non-alkene functional groups to generate a tetrahydropyridine (“TET-ra-HYD-ro-PEER-id-een”) in a Diels–Alder reaction. Schiff bases are an example of these compounds.

Hydrogenating sulfolene forms sulfolane, a solvent commonly used in this technique to purify aromatic hydrocarbons. In the lab, this technique is usually performed in a separatory funnel with aqueous and organic solvents.

answers: synthetic a priori [accept underlined portions in either order; prompt on synthetic; prompt on a priori]
parts: Name this type of statement that can be verified without experience, even though its predicate is not merely contained in its subject. The Critique of Pure Reason is an attempt to uncover how this type of knowledge, such as geometry, is possible.
Kant suggests that knowledge of geometry is possible because these two concepts are a priori intuitions. These two concepts are united into four dimensions in the theory of relativity.
Kant lays out his “Metaphysical Exposition” of the concepts of space and time in this first section of the Critique of Pure Reason, which is followed by the much longer “Logic” section.

answers: harmony [accept Harmonielehre or Theory of Harmony]
Arnold Schoenberg (The construct is the tone row.)
farben [accept the Farben chord or Klangfarbenmelodie; prompt on color]
parts: Name this title concept of a textbook that inspired a 1985 John Adams orchestral piece. Antonio Vivaldi wrote a collection of concertos titled for The Contest Between [this concept] and Invention.

The 1910 textbook Harmonielehre was written by this composer and theorist, who also invented an influential theoretical construct with retrograde, inverted, and inverted retrograde varieties in the 1920s.

With Klang and melodie, this word names a technique discussed in Harmonielehre in which a musical line is split between multiple instruments. This word names the third of Schoenberg’s Five Pieces for Orchestra, which is constructed entirely from its namesake chord.
Name this country that contests Nagorno-Karabakh with Armenia.
The Azerbaijani hub of Nagorno-Karabakh is this city built by Javanshir ruler Panah Ali Khan. The Armenian meliks ruled a state centered on this city.
During World War I, Armenians were massacred in Baku by the Army of Islam, headed by this man, who oversaw the Armenian Genocide.

answers: flagella [or cilia; or flagellum; or cilium] (The taxon is the dinoflagellates.)
parts: Name this whip-like cellular structure whose axoneme has a 9-plus-2 structure of microtubules among eukaryotes.

Flagella are important morphological characters in eukaryotic systematics. A single, posterior flagellum distinguishes flagellated cells from this taxon, which includes animals and fungi and is now grouped with the Amoebozoa into the supergroup Amorphea.

Phylogenomic analyses have shown that many taxa of unicellular eukaryotes that were originally described using morphological evidence lack this property of including all descendants of a most recent common ancestor. Taxa with this property form a clade.

answers: R [or rhotic consonant; or intrusive R]
parts: Name this “intrusive” consonant that can appear between a word-final non-high vowel and a word-initial vowel in varieties of British English.

Intrusive R is a form of this phenomenon, which describes sound changes at morpheme or word boundaries. In Mandarin, the “tone” form of this phenomenon occurs in the phrase “nǐ hǎo,” as the first of two consecutive third tones becomes second tone instead.
The term “sandhi” comes from this language’s word for “joining.” Pāṇini wrote a treatise on the grammar of this Indian language in which the Vedas are written.

Name these two poets, both known for their sensual themes, who met for two hours in Camden in 1884. In a letter to George Cecil Ives referencing that meeting, one of these men wrote that “I have the kiss of the other poet still on my lips.”

Wilde was first exposed to Whitman’s poetry via William Michael Rossetti’s highly sanitized edition of this book, which cut many of its homoerotic poems. This Whitman collection contains “Song of Myself.”
In the sensual eleventh section of “Song of Myself,” a woman peeks out of some blinds and watches 28 young men perform this activity, which she imagines herself doing alongside them.

answers: aerogels [prompt on gels; prompt on colloids or colloidal suspensions or colloidal dispersions] (That process is supercritical drying.)
parts: Name these materials manufactured by placing the starting material in a pressure vessel, filling the vessel with liquid carbon dioxide, heating the carbon dioxide beyond its critical point, and then isothermally depressurizing the vessel. These materials retain the shape of the starting material with little shrinkage.

Ambient-pressure drying to create aerogels relies on performing this process on pore surfaces to prevent bond formation under drying stresses. This process creates a protective oxide layer that is less likely to corrode.
Aerogels are some of the best of these materials out there. These materials reduce heat transfer.
Name this historian and former republican operative who worked for Richard Nixon’s 1968 Presidential campaign. He argued for prioritization of southern states in The Emerging Republican Majority.
Phillips’s southern strategy was used by the GOP to elect this President in 1980 and 1984.

This Nixon speechwriter called Phillips “a genius of sorts.” He called the 1992 DNC the “greatest single exhibition of cross-dressing in American political history” during a speech describing a “culture war” in America.

answers: Section d’Or [or Golden Section; or Puteaux Group]
parts: Name this artist who developed the papier collé (“pop-yay ko-LAY”) technique for his painting Fruit Dish and Glass, which was painted during a period that also included Man with a Guitar and Violin and Candlestick.
Along with Pablo Picasso, Braque founded this artistic movement that was characterized by earthy hues and multiple, fractured perspectives in its Synthetic branch.

Lacking Braque and Picasso’s exclusive deal with Daniel Kahnweiler, this Cubist group exhibited their work in salons. Albert Gleizes (“glez”) and Jean Metzinger (“met-san-ZHAY”) were part of this group with a colorful, geometrically inspired name.

answers: Ingeborg Bachmann Prize [prompt on Bachmann Prize]
parts: Emine Sevgi Özdamar’s (“EH-mee-neh SEV-ghee OOZ-da-mar’s”) semi-autobiographical novels are about her experiences as a person of this ethnicity living in Germany.
Emine Sevgi Özdamar was the first Turkish author to win this prestigious German literary award named for the author of Malina.
According to Özdamar, her first words in German were a request for Benno Besson, a student of this author of Mother Courage and Her Children, to teach her this author’s approach to theater.

answers: lava sledding [or sled surfing; or He’e holua; do not accept or prompt on “surfing”]
parts: One way they honor him is by placing these things called niho palaoa on images of him. More commonly known versions of these objects from Hawaii are made from puka shells.

Another event during Makahiki involves this practice, commonly done on Keauhou (“keh-OW-ho”) with the use of a 12-foot-long papa holua. Despite its dangerous nature, it was almost exclusively practiced by chiefs and royalty.

Unlike lava sledding, a no longer extant event called mokomoko involves this sport. In Greek myth, Pollux was regarded for his prowess in this sport, whose competitors used himantes and sphairai to protect themselves.

answers: Sistine Chapel [or Cappella Sistina; or Sacellum Sixtinum; prompt on Cappella Magna or Great Chapel]
parts: Name this Ottoman sultan who paid off European courts to imprison his rebellious brother Cem (“jem”) Sultan. This sultan ordered an invasion of the Italian city of Otranto.

After being defeated by Bayezid II, Cem Sultan fled to this island, where he was hosted by Pierre d’Aubusson. In 1522, soldiers under Philippe Villiers de L’Isle-Adam (“veel-YAY duh LEEL-ah-DOM”) withstood a six-month siege here before being expelled on generous terms.

The Knights Hospitaller brought Cem Sultan to Rome on the request of Pope Innocent VIII, who was paid by Bayezid to retain him there. Innocent used that money to construct this chapel, which soon housed Michelangelo’s Last Judgment.
